title: How does anthropological knowledge improve people's lives? - Quora

response.answer_text: For this former student of anthropology and world religions, it led to a realization that all religions have more in common than they have in differences. This is a big thing, because it means that no matter what your culture, we all tend to think and believe in very similar ways. It also taught me the importance of symbolic actions, and how easily that can be misunderstood given a particular socio-cultural-historical perspective. Here’s an example: The British insisted upon raising their flag to show their conquest/superiority over a native population. Their flagpoles kept getting cut down - of course they were furious. But the flags weren’t the issue - to the indigenous population, the poles were the issue.

For me? It answers my curiosity about “our” (humankind’s) development; e.g., I find the ‘lifestyle’ of the cavemen circa 35,000 B.C. or so in the Northern and Asian areas interesting, AND it was useful to know about those kinds of things when I was studying survival (put me ahead in the military - I could actually knap rocks and make primitive shelters, shoes, etc., using old techniques.)

If you look up the word “anthropological” you will find that this means “science of the natural history of mankind”. How could having the knowledge of the history of mankind not improve people’s lives? “anthropo-” means "pertaining to man or human beings” philanthropy for example means “love of mankind” You may want to use the website http://etymology.com
